channel.description:

item.description:

[quote=“JavaTC, post:45, topic:533584”][quote author=CoonHunter link=topic=652376.msg4379705#msg4379705 date=1383155220]

[/quote]
Doesn’t mean she wasn’t mentally ill. She can say or think she’s sane but it doesn’t mean she is for sure.[/quote]
We have medical doctors of all kinds, including phsycological doctors. She has no signs of any medical problem.

This is why I don’t care to talk about the correctional facilities business with people who don’t work there. You guys can hear that it took us 2 hours to get a man to the clinic for his appointment, and you think were just being slow. When in reality there is ALOT going on in the inside of a prison that you will never see or hear about. Nobody really understands until they work at one.

EDIT: Here is an example between what the public hears, and what is actually going on. Here is what the public hears:
http://www.hattiesburgamerican.com/article/20130903/NEWS11/309030001/

What actually went on: Tyler Smith popped out of his cell and into Clifton Majors cell during a 10-17 medical (inmate medical emergency) that was in progress on another lockdown section, creating a shortage of officers on the lockdown section Tyler Smith was in. This gave him ample time. Clifton Majors was also not beaten to death, his throat was slit, then his head crushed in, eyes also stabbed through.

When was Clifton Majors said to have died? When he arrived at our clinic, when in fact (Yes I had responded to the killing) I had to help carry Clifton Majors to the ambulance, he was dead before medical personel even arrived for him. Tyler Smith shouted down the hall as me and another officer escorted him to the holding tank “I killed that bitch, he aint coming back” many times, etc. He literally admitted to this, and was proud of it. I also personally removed two chanks and a broken broom stick from the crime scene.

Tyler Smith and Clifton Majors are both ‘Simon City Royal’ affiliated, a gang that has recently had many of it members clashing. Remember, just because the news says no weapons involved, doesn’t mean anything.

item.title: Death penalty?
item.dc:creator: @ry60003333 ry60003333
item.description:
@ry60003333 wrote:

The main problem I have with the death penalty is that there is a very high rate of false conviction, especially with death penalty sentences that were given before DNA testing was a thing. You can’t un-kill someone, so if the government realized that they have made a mistake, they cannot fix it.

Also, if they make a mistake on purpose, it provides a nice way to get rid of people. I kind of feel like being in jail for the rest of your life is a lot worse then dying, dying seems like the easy way out.

item.title: Death penalty?
item.dc:creator: @CoonHunter CoonHunter
item.description:
@CoonHunter wrote:

[quote=“Bowser jr, post:39, topic:533584”][quote author=CoonHunter link=topic=652376.msg4379441#msg4379441 date=1383078867]
You all act as if every murderer is put under the Death Penalty, when in fact its actually not used as often as you would think. Currently at the correctional facility I work at we only have 2 Death-Row offenders. Only one of which I actually know the crimes to. Want to know? No? Im telling you anyways.

She killed both of her teenage children, then baked her baby in the oven with various sauces and spices. When the baby was done cooking, she took the “meal” to her parents house (the childrens grandmothers) and attempted to feed the baby to them. The grandparents didn’t even know what it was she was trying to feed them until she cut into the baby. - This woman has only been on the DP for a couple years now.

Did you know - It costs an adverage of 35k per year to house an inmate?

Private Prisons - Actually there is an incentive. The state (or federal, depending on who has “ownership” [lack of a better word] of the inmate) pay the private prison to house them.

In my honest opinion. Yes, all states need to have the DP because sometimes its just going to be cheaper in the long run. Remember, being put on death row doesn’t mean you probably wont naturally die in the facility of other causes first. It takes many (ive herd as many as 50) years before you either get released from DP or get executed.
[/quote]
The woman in your example is mentally ill, you don’t kill such people. Private prisons have no incentive to lower the recidivism rate, as that would lessen the demand for prisons.[/quote]
You make that assumption without any proof. She sees a Phsycological doctor weekly yes, but she has not been diagnosed with anything except post-traumatic stress disorder. All inmates at the correctional facility I work at will see the phsyc doctor at least once a month. Remember, some (like the female) are locked up 24/7 because she will fight just to get her back into her cell, which causes more time in lockdown.

Do not make an assumption about an inmate just by a story you’ve herd. We have a mental “hospital” just down the road about 1.5 miles from the facility I work at. There is very few people who come to prison and need to be transfered over there.

The female was not mentally ill either. She was tired of dealing with her kids. Thats exactly what she will tell you.

item.dc:creator: @the_wanderer The Wanderer
item.description:
@the_wanderer wrote:

[quote=“CoonHunter, post:35, topic:533584”]Did you know - It costs an adverage of 35k per year to house an inmate?[/quote] Did you know it costs on average 1.26 million dollars to execute a single person in Kansas and more in other states? Now considering your average is correct, that is 36 years in jail on average. So unless the person spends more than 36 years in jail, it is cheaper to just lock them up until they die. Yes I know you said 50 years, but that is definitely not the average. Also, if you want to take a person who could be in jail for fifty years, it is nearly the same costs as putting them on death row means you have to house them for those fifty years. So no matter if you put them in jail or death row your tax dollars are paying for them to be housed. Only difference is with the death penalty is they get to repeal and repeal and repeal until there is 100% certainty they are at fault. Why not just lock them up in solitary confinement and be done with it?

[quote=“CoonHunter, post:35, topic:533584”]Yes, all states need to have the DP because sometimes its just going to be cheaper in the long run.[/quote] No no no no no. Look up the facts then come back. It will save yourself the embarrassment.

[quote=“CoonHunter, post:35, topic:533584”]Remember, being put on death row doesn’t mean you probably wont naturally die in the facility of other causes first. It takes many (ive herd as many as 50) years before you either get released from DP or get executed.[/quote] Yes! So why put them on death row if they will just die a normal death as if they were in prison. Only difference, as I stated earlier, is that you have to pay for all of the court cases and repeals and whatnot for the death penalty.

As far as that woman goes, she deserves to be locked up for life, but I am not spending extra money just so people can have their revenge.

item.dc:creator: @the_wanderer The Wanderer
item.description:
@the_wanderer wrote:

Politics perhaps, but not economics when your economy is in dire need of help. It’s like the adage penny smart but dollar dumb. Why waste time and energy right now saving pennies and perhaps dollars in the future when you can save dollars right now. You know just as well as I do that no law can easily be passed through congress, especially if it involves private businesses. All of those prisons will lobby against the bill and it will take a lot of time and effort to get that bill passed. Why waste that time and energy when you won’t be getting large returns immediately

And perhaps if you created an incentive then they would. Perhaps if their was an inspection that decided how well a prison was at correcting their inmates and then you would fill the prison with the highest approval rating first. This would be an incentive for private prisons because they receive money based on how many inmates they have.

Or a simpler solution would be to raise the bar for private prisons since they have to sign a contract with the government. If the correctional facilities are not up to par then they do not receieve governmental funding.

And with what you said about lobbying, then that is why we should get rid of lobbying haha. It produces bad legislation. Although I have no idea how it ever could be removed. Only way is if somehow all of congress had a good moral compass and realized lobbying was malignant to our country and abolished it.

item.title: Death penalty?
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

[quote=“Bowser jr, post:23, topic:533584”][quote author=The Wanderer link=topic=652376.msg4373766#msg4373766 date=1381505282]

Nope. Waste of money. Cheaper to lock them in jail. Last thing America needs right now is to spend more money on criminals.

Wrong, what you need is to spend more money on criminals to make them into functional citizens.

Surely that shouldn’t be America’s number one priority? I understand the benefits of spending more money on them so they can go out into the work force and benefit America, but I don’t think America is in the financial standpoint to do so. I highly doubt that would fix our economical problems, which I would consider to be the number one priority. I think fixing bad legislature and foregoing lobbying would benefit America the most, not fixing the correctional facilities. In most countries they call it bribery, in America it is lobbying…

By spending more money you don’t get the people back into your prisons. And you’re wasting money when people don’t get help. You also need to nationalize your prison system, as prisons should NOT be in private hands.

I think that is a great idea, and like I said I agree that improved correctional facilities will benefit America in the long run. However, the problem is that the returns deal in the long run. I don’t think America should be looking at long term benefits of saving money at the moment. I also disagree that the prison system should be nationalized. There definitely should be government-run prisons, but it should not be illegal to run a private prison. America is based on entrepreneurship, so if someone found a niche and made a prison, then that is fair game. However, public prisons should be of higher standards to push the private prisons to be at higher standards in order to compete. That is my philosophy for the national healthcare problem too.
[/quote]
Private prisons have no incentive to do a good job, that is why you should outlaw them.
And you should ALWAYS look at the long term effect of politics.[/quote]
If you incentivise a low recidivism rate (i.e., rewarding prisons that have outgoing prisoners who make 1, 2, and 5 year milestones without reoffending) then private prisons would do a good job. The problem is that the incentive doesn’t currently exist.

Your suggestion isn’t practical. America likes privatisation just as much as they like their guns and carburetor engines.
